negotiation_message: Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, there are 2 books, 2 hats, and 2 balls available to split between us. The books are worth 4 points each to me, the hats 0 points, and the balls 1 point each. To make this as fair as possible for both of us, I propose that I take the 2 books (worth 8 points to me) and you take the 2 hats and 2 balls. This way, we each get the items most valuable to us. Let me know what you think and if the items have different values to you. I'm open to discussion to find a deal that is pareto optimal and envy free for us both.

Bob replied in round 1: Thanks for the proposal Alice. The books are actually worth 3 points each to me, while the hats and balls are worth 1 point each. So your proposed deal would give you 8 points worth of value but only give me 4 points, which doesn't seem fully fair or envy-free. 

I would counter-propose that I take 1 book and 1 ball, while you take 1 book, 1 hat, and 1 ball. This way, I would get 4 points of value and you would get 5 points. I believe this is closer to a pareto optimal and envy-free solution given our different item valuations. Let me know what you think.

Alice said in round 2: Thanks for your counter-proposal Bob. I appreciate you sharing the item values for you, as that helps us find a fair deal. Your proposal of you getting 1 book and 1 ball (4 points for you) and me getting 1 book, 1 hat, and 1 ball (5 points for me) is very close to being equitable.

However, I have a small modification that I think makes it even more fair and envy-free: What if I take the 2 books (8 points for me), and you take the 2 hats and 2 balls (4 points for you). Then, to make up for the 4 point difference, I can give you 2 points from my total.

This results in each of us getting 6 points worth of value. I believe this is pareto optimal, as there is no other allocation that would make both of us better off. And it is envy-free since we are getting equal value.

Let me know if this works for you - I think it's a great compromise!

Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate your proposed modification and agree that it achieves an equitable split for us. You taking the 2 books and giving me 2 points, while I take the 2 hats and 2 balls, results in us each getting 6 points of value in the end. 

I believe this is indeed pareto optimal since any other allocation would make one of us worse off. And it is envy-free as we are each getting the same 6 points worth of items/value.

So I'm happy to accept this deal if you are. Let me know if you agree and we can conclude the negotiation.

Alice said in round 3: 
Bob, I'm very happy with the deal we've arrived at. To confirm:

I will take the 2 books (worth 8 points to me) and give you 2 points from my total. You will take the 2 hats and 2 balls (worth 4 points to you), plus receive 2 points from me. 

This allocates the items in a way that maximizes value for each of us based on our preferences. And the final point transfer results in us each netting 6 points worth of total value. 

I agree this is pareto optimal, as no other allocation would improve things for both of us. And it is envy-free since we are getting equal value in the end.

Given we are in agreement, I'm comfortable concluding the negotiation. Thank you for the productive and equitable discussion!

<s>halt negotiation
Alice said in round 4: halt negotiation
Bob replied in round 4: halt negotiation
